contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Queen Elizabeth's Pocket Pistol.JPG|right|thumb|300px|Queen Elizabeth's Pocket Pistol on display within [[Dover Castle]]]] '''Queen Elizabeth's Pocket Pistol''' is a cannon built in 1544 in [[Utrecht (city)|Utrecht]] by Jan Tolhuys, before [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth]] came to the throne.<ref>http://www.doverpages.co.uk/dover/pocket_pistol.htm</ref> The gun was presented to [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]] by [[Maximiliaan van Egmond]], Count of [[Buren]] and [[Stadtholder]] of [[Friesland]] as a gift for his young daughter Elizabeth.<ref name="panoramio.com">[http://www.panoramio.com/photo/5381732 Panoramio - Photo of Queen Elizabeth's Pocket Pistol, Naafi Restaurant, Knights Road, Dover Castle, Kent, UK (1)]</ref> The cannon measures 24 ft in length and fired 4.75 inch calibre cannon balls. The cannon is decorated with engravings of fruit, flowers, [[grotesque]]s, and figures symbolizing [[Liberty]], [[Victory]] and [[Fame]].<ref>[http://www.dover.freeuk.com/garrison/pistol.htm The Pocket Pistol]</ref> There is also a [[Tudor dynasty|Tudor]] coat of arms which includes a verse in Dutch, which translates in English as ''Break, tear every wall and rampart, Am I called, Across mountain and valley, pierces my ball, By me striken''. Between 1613 and 1622 the gun was used and was found to be capable of firing a 10 lb ball a distance of 2000 yards.<ref>"Treasures of Britain" by Drive Publications Limited, for the Automobile Association. P.167</ref> Before the [[English Civil War]] it guarded the [[cliffs of Dover]]<ref>"The History of the Castle, Town and Port of Dover" by Reverend S. P. H. Statham, Rector of St Mary-in-the-Castle (ie St Mary-in-Castro) (Longmans, Green, and Co., 1899</ref> and propaganda of the time claimed it could fire a 12 lb ball seven miles.<ref>[http://www.flickr.com/photos/jorolat/1621805950/ Dover Castle - Queen Elizabeth's Pocket Pistol, Kent, UK (1) | Flickr - Photo Sharing!]</ref> Some even said its shot could reach France if the gun was properly maintained<ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=50925 Dorsington - Down-Ampney | A Topographical Dictionary of England (pp. 78-84)]</ref> though this is an exaggeration; tests done in the 1970s with similar [[Basilisk (cannon)|basilisks]] have a more realistic range of 1200 yards with a 10 lb ball.<ref name="panoramio.com"/> In 1644 King [[Charles I of England|Charles I's]] forces in Cornwall reported capturing from the [[Earl of Essex]] '49 Peeces of faire Brasse Ordnance (taken then and the day before) among which was the great [[Basilisk (cannon)|Basilisco]] of Dover â€¦'.<ref>''[[Mercurius Aulicus]]'' Week 36, British Library, Thomason Tracts E.10[20]</ref> This cannon has since been identified as Queen Elizabeth's Pocket Pistol.<ref>W. Y. Carmen, 2004. ''A History of Firearms: From Earliest Times to 1914''. Dover Publications, p.45</ref> Later that year the gun saw action at the siege of [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]] where it was recaptured by the [[Roundheads]] and used at the Siege of [[Sheffield]].<ref>"Dover Castle" by R. Allen Brown (Her Majesty's Stationery Office, HMSO 1974</ref> The cannon can be seen at [[Dover Castle]] on a replacement carriage made in the 18th century from captured French guns.<ref name="panoramio.com"/> A copy of the cannon is displayed in [[Buren]] The Netherlands next to the museum of the Dutch Royal Family.
